summary_P: There were many stories about Achilles and Patroclus. Briseis knew none of them when she was captured.   All she knew was that this war had nothing to do with her, yet it had cost her her husband, her city and her freedom. When Achilles had come to her for the first time, she'd still been frozen inside, her arms still remembering the last time she'd held Mynes, her nostrils still full with the stench of the sacking of Lyrnessus. Her mind fled somewhere else as he took her, the sudden fall from the king's daughter-in-law to slave too much for her to understand.  When one of the older slaves in Achilles' tent had shown her her new duties the next day, she'd said in a kindly voice, meant to be comforting, "At least he's young and handsome. And he's not violent in bed. You could have done worse, child."  It hadn't felt like it at the time, but as time passed Briseis realised that she'd been right. The camp of the Greeks was filled with warriors far from their homes, from their wives, years of war making bloodlust second-nature to most of them. It didn't lessen the ache Briseis still felt whenever she remembered her former life, but she came to appreciate the strict discipline her new master enforced among his Myrmidons. No one except for him ever laid a hand on her, and when he did he behaved almost courteously. Closing her eyes, she could sometimes imagine he was her husband, back when Mynes had been the stranger she'd been given to in marriage. Hers had not been a love match.   It took longer for her to realise that Achilles' behaviour was not due to any particular gentleness in his character.  On the contrary, after the first real battle, not just a skirmish, Briseis shrank back at the sight of him. She'd heard of Achilles' unmatched might, yet she understood only now that fighting was his purpose, that he'd honed himself into a weapon everyone was right to fear. He certainly scared Briseis, and although she knew that it was her duty to look after her master, she hesitated to go to him, afraid of the uncontrolled violence that was still radiating from him.  As she lingered at the entrance to the tent, she realised Achilles wasn't alone. She'd seen Patroclus before of course, never far from his commander's side, the one person around whom Achilles' laugh seemed to come easily. This was especially apparent when they practised their sword play or wrestling, circling each other with wide grins on their faces. Achilles always won in the end, but even Briseis could see that their fighting resembled nothing more than a well-practised dance, their bodies recognising each other joyfully. She realised only now, gauging whether it was safe to enter, how far that recognition went.  Briseis knew about the love between men and youths, of course, yet because Achilles and Patroclus were both grown men it had never occurred to her that they might still play bed games, the way she'd been told was normal among many younger men. If it had, she would likely have assumed Achilles to be the erastes - after all, despite his boyish looks, he was higher in rank, stronger, the son of an immortal.   Instead the two men seemed just as perfectly matched in this as they were in their fight practice. They collided with each other with a force that sent shivers down Briseis' spine, violence turned into hard kisses and firm grasps. It was nothing that Briseis would want for herself, but between these two it seemed perfect.   Quietly, she moved back, leaving them to their love. Because that was what it was, she grew more and more certain as she watched them more closely from that day on. Achilles might be gentle with her, yet it was still rape, not love. What he shared with Patroclus, however, was like a force of nature, as if neither man was quite himself unless they were together.   Patroclus only spoke to her one time. He was as much a warrior as his liege, but without the dark current that seethed under Achilles' invulnerable skin. When he promised, "He'll make you his bride once this is over," Briseis believed him and took it as the consolation it was meant to be. At least as the wife of Achilles she'd be inviolate, untouchable.  Already Achilles' reputation protected her during the days trapped in Agamemnon's tent, sparing her the Mycenean king's attentions, because despite all his posturing even he knew to be afraid of the Myrmidon hero's wrath. Briseis wasn't, not anymore, not as long as Patroclus was there, at Achilles' side, in his heart.   Therefore her blood ran cold when she heard he had fallen, and her eyes itched with unbidden tears. What would become of her, now that Achilles had lost his anchor, his other half? Would Achilles' violence spill over when he came to her, without Patroclus to reign him in?  She never found out.   Although supposedly all of this had been caused by a quarrel over her, when she was returned like a consolation price, Achilles had no taste for anything except grief and revenge. She was not surprised when he died at the end, in the midst of victory for the Greeks. Truthfully, he'd been half-dead already. Preparing her master for the afterlife, the tears she cried were for the kinder fate Patroclus' death had robbed her of as well as for Achilles, whose ashes would soon be mixed with those of his lover. Just like Briseis herself, he had turned out to be nothing but another victim of this war, although one that was unlikely to be forgotten.  Growing old, a slave in some Myrmidon's house, many asked Briseis about her time in the Trojan War. Briseis answered willingly, telling them of the famed Achilles, and of Patroclus, his companion. What was she but a footnote in their story, after all?

summary_P: 1  The black veil gives a women decent privacy with her thoughts.  Corrie Worth, newly widowed, brushed crimson on her lips with a practiced hand, adjusted her hat over graying curls, and lowered the veil. Black gloves, bought at Woolworth's, weren't of the quality usually demanded by the wife of the third-richest mine owner in Harlan County; but sometimes keeping up appearances meant letting down standards.  She stepped into the waiting black Cadillac with the assurance of a woman who'd been driven all her life.  2  Her very first Cadillac had appeared when she was walking to school, barefoot to save her shoes, on a road more stones than dirt.  Looking back at herself with grown-up eyes, she saw an underfed girl who at sixteen looked no more than a city girl's twelve, still in braids, with her calico dress a little too short but no money to replace it. Her mother did miracles, farming the rocky soil and the steep mountainsides, but weather's a fickle friend.  The back door of the Cadillac opened, and Dixon Worth offered her a bag of peppermint candy to get in. She was too stupid with hunger to say no.  3  For Dixon Worth's funeral, the preacher took as his text 2 Corinthians 4:8-9. We are troubled on every side, yet not distressed; we are perplexed, but not in despair; persecuted, but not forsaken; cast down, but not destroyed.  The slip of a girl on the other side of the church wept with the concentration of a person who's biting the inside of her cheek and thinking about when her dog died.  Corrie would have lent her a veil if they could have admitted to knowing each other.  4  Sheriff J.H. Blair was one of the first to shake the preacher's hand after the service. Corrie suspected she could have danced naked on Dixon's coffin without shaking Blair from his certainty that he'd caught the right men when he jailed those striking miners as murderers.  What will they stoop to next? had become the center of dinner-party conversation among the mine-owning families. A new widow wasn't invited, of course, but word got back to her. This time, they attacked one of us on in the dark. Next, they'll be murdering us in our beds.  A more horrifying idea followed, one that had to be couched in a whisper. Next, they'll be raping our daughters.  Remembering how she'd wed Dixon--trembling and shamed, fearing that she'd made a baby, fearing that she'd incited him somehow--Corrie could almost laugh at fearing the miners.  A black veil hides a widow's unseemly swings of emotion.  5  The girl waited until Corrie had laid her rose on the coffin before she stepped forward with a straggling handful of daisies.  She had the fine features and sinuous movements of a naiad somehow stranded in these coal-rich hills, forced to guard a stream where the mines spewed waste. She might have meant to marry a coal-miner or go to Lexington for factory work or even chase the Hollywood men from the recording companies to get a contract singing songs older than the hills.  For less than a flicker of rain, Corrie's green eyes met the girl's clear blue gaze. The girl mouthed thank you.  6  Corrie had guessed when she found the pink lipstick on Dixon's silk handkerchief, but she hadn't cared until word got back through the servants that little Araminta Sizemore had tried slicing her wrists.  She'd sent a pair of cream-colored gloves--the good ones, from the shop in Lexington--with a message written small and folded into one finger.  7  Her own nightmares about miners involved hanged men, ropes still around their necks, accusing her. Once Dixon's safely in the ground, she'll turn to Sheriff J.H. Blair for comfort, and he'll mysteriously lose the keys to the jail, just long enough for the miners to escape. Their lives won't be worth much in Harlan County, but that's nothing new.  The thought of Blair sweating and grunting atop her nauseated Corrie, but it wasn't not right that any more people suffer for Dixon's sins.  8  Peppermint tea, so refreshing was the murmur among guests at the house after the funeral. Talking about Dixon's murder wasn't proper, not in front of his widow.  9  Raising the pick over her head had taken all Corrie's strength, but the wet, crushing noise when it entered Dixon's head had made the effort worth it.

summary_P: "Young women, I've brought you the man who laughed at you, who ridiculed my rites. Now punish him!" said Dionysus.   The Maenads, mad with rage at the violation of their sacred gathering, shook the tree, upon which that royal intruder sat, so hard that Pentheus fell out of it like an apple from the branch. He rolled downhill, the women were at his heels, then he jumped to his feet and ran like the hare, dashing wildly through the forest, breaking brambles and treading thorns. His white robes, which had disguised him as one of them, fluttered like a flag in the wind and not far behind him were the Maenads, running fast like jaguars, some on two feet and some on four, all in varying states of undress. They laughed feverishly and their animal howling and screeching echoed behind him, all throughout the forest; everywhere the Maenads came after him like hounds after the fox.  Out of the bramble and the thorns, Dionysus appeared in Pentheus' path. Sweet were his lips but dark his eyes, such as the gazes that lovers share in the night. "Halt," he said and Pentheus stopped, held on the spot, unable to will his body any other way. "There is that great stag, who is straying in our fields. That stag shall be my sacrifice," said Dionysus.   Hearing his call, the group of Maenads came rushing to him, approaching from all sides, encircling their rare catch. Trapped and desperate, Pentheus spun in a circle around, pleading with the women who approached him slowly now like the cat sneaking up on the mouse. "Do you not see who I am? Underneath these robes woven with gold it is I, Pentheus, your son, your kin, your master, your king!" He tore his headdress away, revealing himself, and some of them recognized him and some of them did not. His mother Agave saw a lion with firm loins, some saw a stag with heavy antlers, others saw a wild boar and others did see him as he was, but too great was their lust for him and their righteous anger to change their paths.   "Spoil him," said the twice-born Semeilos. His voice was a terrible whisper in the trees.   Dionysus, who breaks the chains, bestowed upon those women that, which nature had not allotted to them. He gave them the strength of beasts and the power to mend their bodies into shapes fit for their lecherous purpose. At his behest, one took her thyrsus and touched it to her loins and such transformed them into those of a man. Another followed her example but the lean girl became like a hound and another one rough and heavy-set became like a bull.  The three transformed came running on all fours like the hungry wolves and behind them followed the rest of the Maenads, dancing and singing and screaming with joy. The first of the women jumped on Pentheus as he lay prostrate, pleading at the smiling god's feet. By his power, her fingers turned into talons and she ripped the fine dress off Pentheus' back, revealing the proud warrior's body to eyes red with hunger and rage. Terrifying Pentheus trembled fearfully. He pressed his lips hotly to Dionysus's feet, kissing them in all too late reverence, but no begging would move the avenger to mercy.   Wanton with rage like the bulls freed of their tethers, the half-woman pulled Pentheus back into their midst and onto all fours, into the embrace of beasts. From behind she mounted him and he cried out, for it was the first time he had been used such and she used him cruelly like men use their slaves, finding his virginal clench a thing most pleasant to break. And break he did, whimpering undignifiedly, when she had her fill and then came the next, the dog and the bull and the boar and the horse and the bear, all hermaphrodite creatures with the loins of male beasts and the sweet laughter of women bellowing from their heaving breasts.   Turning him over from one to the other like the drinking cup, they mounted cruelly, they kissed greedily, they scratched, they bit, they tore, and they spilled. Soon they drew blood from him, tearing like skewers into the lees of his belly. Blood was only incense to their frenzy and all greater became their brutality and the greater his cries. One, all human was she, bit his neck, blunt teeth crushing and grinding like millstones. Another took his arm and twisted it behind his back until it broke in three parts and hung slack and useless from the socket. Another drew her thyrsus, slick with honey, over his belly. Where it touched, the skin split in two like an overripe fruit, spilling dark red wine and clear clotted milk, drenching wet the ground below their feet. The last one grabbed him by the stones, pulled until they came off and swallowed them whole. Pentheus' eyes rolled in their sockets like those of the sweet heifer on the altar of sacrifice; twisting and turning, he screamed and screamed.  Dionysus stood unmoving. "How you dance now, how you laugh," said he, "are these not the reveries you sought to see? Oh, dear cousin, you shall enjoy my hospitality." At once, the Maenads, bloodied, dirty, and panting with lust, withdrew in a circle around Pentheus, who lay in a trembling heap of tatters. Then as if pulled up by a string he rose from the pool of his blood, upright and the neck stretched like a crane. Moving his fingers left and right in uncharted gestures, Dionysus made him dance beautifully. Pentheus threw his limbs left and right and his broken bones cracked the tune. The rags of his dress that hung off his body followed each move and so did his innards when disturbed by the motions they came spilling from the cleft in his stomach like flower garlands swaying in the wind. The blood splashed up high from under his soles, like water from a puddle after the rain, and mad now with pain, he foamed from the mouth.  "Look how he shakes and trembles. Listen to the moans of his ecstasy," said Dionysus and all that he said was true, because he willed it so that Pentheus' pain was also pleasure, two currents of water flowing from the same source. Pentheus danced, he laughed, and he cried and in that moment he saw up the river and in the currents of his own flesh, what no one had seen before him; Dionysus Mystes in his manifold forms, ever devouring and ever devoured, tearing and torn, the ceaseless hunger of the world, and he saw himself in the god's jaws, man and woman alike, moaning with pleasure as the teeth ground him to red and white gruel.  Thus at last by Dionysus' command and the Maenad's hands, he was torn limb from limb, split in two and three and four and ever smaller parts. The young women wreathed themselves crowns of his guts, entwining them with flowers upon their heads and the old ones drenched their greying hair in his blood as though it were the sweetest myrrh. They ate his innards still steaming hot and raw, they gnawed his flesh down to the bone and wolf cubs carried the bones away. Only his head remained in one piece; his mother Agave carried it as a trophy back to Thebes, where he was born. Meanwhile, the Maenads fell asleep in the embrace of the forest, nestling up to each other like kittens after a good meal.

summary_P: Cassandra, dressed as a messenger boy, found her way into the tent where the Greek Army was holding Iphigenia captive.  At first, her eyes adjusting to the dimness, she saw no one. Then what had looked like a heap of dirty laundry in the corner resolved itself into a woman, loosely covered by a stained linen cloth. The top half of her face was hidden by a mask, as if the soldiers didn't want to be reminded of who she really was.   A thick rope around Iphigenia's neck was linked to a sturdy post. It had just enough slack to allow her to sit or lie down. Her ankles and wrists were not restrained at the moment, but Cassandra could see the skin was raw there from bindings used recently. And she would be bound again, come nightfall, unless Cassandra intervened.  Cassandra didn't want to see what they'd been doing to her, but her inexorable, inescapable prophetic vision showed Iphigenia on a narrow table, on her knees, held in the chains. Her arms stretched behind her. The soldiers sating their lust on her, roughly, while others waited their turn.  They'd been doing it for days.  Ever since Agamemnon had decreed Iphigenia was to be sacrificed, and Calchas had delivered her to this tent -- "to meditate and fast and prepare," he'd said in the King's hearing, knowing full well what would really happen.   The soldiers used her because they were angry.   Angry that they'd been forced to honor vows of allyship taken by their fathers, to leave their lands and families to take up arms over a domestic affair not their own. Angry that they'd been called to battle and then left to languish on the beach near the becalmed ships of war, because Agamemnon had to go and foolishly slay the goddess Artemis's deer. Angry because, when he'd finally decided to act, to seek the advice of the gods on how to atone for his error, he'd refused to do what Calchas -- who had the gift of prophecy from Apollo, and claimed to know Artemis's will -- had said was the necessary thing. He'd dawdled over bringing his daughter to Aulis.   They were even angry that this delicate woman was to be sacrificed to the gods, her throat cut and her heart torn out to be burned on the sacred altar. She should be gracing the household of a deserving man with her noble beauty. Bearing him strong sons. That she was captive amidst them, that they could take her with no consequence, was unnatural. It upset the proper order of things.   That they expressed all this anger by brutalizing Iphigenia night after night made no sense to Cassandra.  But little that men -- human or divine -- did to women made sense to her.  Starting with the question why Iphigenia was to pay the price of her father's error in the first place.   Cassandra had no way of communicating directly with the gods -- except for that one god she vowed she'd sooner die than speak to again. But if she had, she'd certainly have asked Artemis about her demand that Iphigenia's blood be spilled in compensation for the death of her stag at the hands of Agamemnon. Why harm the daughter to punish the father? Was she so insensible of the difference between one human and another? If she valued the lives of her deer so much, how came it that she didn't value the life of this young woman, who had done nothing to harm her? Or, why was she satisfied to receive her as a sacrifice after her body had been sullied in this way?   Even the goddesses were inscrutable to Cassandra. As one who'd received Apollo's gift -- curse -- of prophecy, she could sometimes see how they would act, but the whys were forever closed to her.  Iphigenia raised her head a fraction as Cassandra entered the tent. Perceiving the garb of a man, the princess shrank back, trying in vain to hide herself against the dim wall of the tent. Her mouth twisted into an expression, a combined fear and despair, that tore at the prophetess -- not only because it spoke of Iphigenia's pain, but also because it brought forth a vision of her own future, one that Cassandra hated more than any other.   She saw herself ravaged in the temple of Athena as her beloved Troy burned around her.   Clinging to the goddess's feet, begging for mercy, for intercession, as her clothing was torn from her. As the full weight of the armored warrior, Ajax, fell upon her, and he violated her body again and again, until she felt it slicken with blood, until she knew he had torn her fertility from her.   Her tormentor made sure she saw that vision often. She'd see him, standing by in his gleaming golden sandals, his hair streaming like the rays of the sun. But as warm as was the sun, his eyes were equally as cold. "None of this would have happened if you'd accepted me," he would say. "But you refused to slake the thirst of a god who was parched for you."   She'd replied. Once. "I was a human woman, Lord Apollo. I refused you nothing. How could I? Sooner say that an ant can force a tree to uproot itself and walk to another part of the forest. You wanted me, and you are a god. So, you had me. Every part of my body you wanted, you took and pleasured in, and I could not refuse you your pleasure. I could not even refuse you mine. And then you punished me, and I will live out my life never understanding why."   Apollo's face darkened in anger, the way a thunderhead blots out the sun, and he turned his face away.   She'd never spoken to him again, although he returned to taunt her.  "Lady Iphigenia," Cassandra said. "I am not a man, nor sent from one. I am here to offer you succor."  "Stranger," rasped Iphigenia, "I am parched."  Cassandra approached slowly. She slipped her small, soft hand behind Iphigenia's head to hold it steady. She put aside the mask.   Even as bruised as she was, Iphigenia was one of the most beautiful women Cassandra had ever beheld. How she wished she had more time to get to know her.  She pressed the mouth of her drinking flask to the tormented woman's lips.   "Do not drink too much at any one time," Cassandra reminded her. "The men are training, and then they will be at their meal, and we have some time before they will come here."  Cassandra took the dual-bladed dagger from where it was hidden in her clothing, and unwrapped it.  "I am only removing the rope. I will not hurt you," she reassured the princess. She cut the rope from Iphigenia's neck, then set the dagger on the ground beside them.   In between the sips of water she offered Iphigenia, she laid out the story of her curse, and her vow of revenge against the god and those he favored.  "But how will you revenge yourself against a god?" Iphigenia said. "It is impossible. We humans have no power against them."  "The only thing I can do," Cassandra said, "is to end my life before worse happens to me. That way, I will at least thwart his desire to bring me a long lifetime of suffering. It is little enough. But the gods are not used to being opposed. It will gall him that I've put myself out of his reach forever, for his brother Hades is possessive of the shades he's collected and will not restore me to him."  Cassandra gave Iphigenia the flask again, then took a sip herself.  "That is where you come in. Princess Iphigenia, I offer to free you and take your place."  Iphigenia turned her huge brown eyes on Cassandra, who wanted to weep for their beauty.  "You must not! I do not deserve your life!"  Cassandra got on her knees in supplication. She embraced the princess's waist, pressing her face between the small breasts, careful not to bruise them further. "I beg you, Iphigenia." She touched her forehead to the woman's hands, kissed the raw wrists. "If you grant me this, I have a request to make in return."  "What is it?" asked the doomed princess.  "I have hidden some gold -- I will tell you where -- that you might live without returning to your father's palace. I wish you to be free and to live as you choose. But should you come across other women who have been misused by gods, or men in the name of gods, and if the anger I feel speaks to you then, you have my blessing to harry them, in my name. Make them pay more than they want to pay for perpetrating such injustices. If any of my heart remains once my shade takes its place in Hades, know that I will cheer you on from that dark place."  Her prophetic gift did not show her what would result from the request. Cassandra hoped against hope that this was because her choices would shift the flow of time, change the future into one unknown, unseen, even by the hated golden god.   But even as she hoped, she expected that Iphigenia would not believe. Would not believe any of it.  Iphigenia's voice was still barely louder than a whisper, but it was a little steadier than it had been. Cassandra fed her a few crumbs of wine-soaked bread, and the princess replied to what Cassandra had told her.  "The golden god asked for your body, gave you the Farsight, took you, and then decreed no one would ever believe your prophecies? But why?"  "I did not give him my love," Cassandra said. "My awe, devotion, worship, body, pleasure, yes. Those were his for the taking. It was not enough."  "The gods are indeed cruel," Iphigenia said. "Look how Artemis has treated me, I who offered her nothing but the deepest devotion my heart could engender. No wonder you vow to deny the golden god the pleasure of your suffering. No wonder you want this even more than life itself. I do not blame you."  This was the part Cassandra could not see. It was strange for her now, being blind to the future, an impenetrable fog in front of her farseeing eye.   She turned to Iphigenia to offer her more bread and water, and saw the young, bruised and battered woman staring blankly at the ceiling, moving her lips slightly.  "Artemis," she saw those lips say, although she heard nothing.   Then Iphigenia's eyes rolled back in her head, and she seemed insensible.  Cassandra feared she had died. But when she put her fingers on the woman's lips, her breath warmed them. So the prophetess sat by her side, watching for long moments the shadows lengthen outside the tent, moistening Iphigenia's lips with water.  Just as she was beginning to truly despair, Iphigenia stirred.  "Artemis came to me, in a vision," she whispered.  "What did she say?"   "She did not decree my sacrifice," said Iphigenia. "Calchas the prophet lied to my father the King. She seeks revenge against him. She asked me to speak to you, Cassandra. Her brother has claimed you, and she dare not directly oppose him in this. But she will help you -- us -- if she can."  Cassandra let out an angry laugh. So even the goddesses could be rendered helpless by their male counterparts.  A bitter tear brimmed in Iphigenia's eye.   "My heart aches for what you plan," she said. "I do not like to think of your death. I do not want you to take my place."  "Think of it instead as a gift. You are letting me exercise a choice, the one choice I've ever had. The choice to say no to a god."  "Cassandra, I will make sure the golden god feels your wrath," Iphigenia said. "Your sacrifice will not be in vain."  They both knew that what Iphigenia promised was impossible. A human could not revenge herself against a god.  But sometimes the only thing to do was to try.  Cassandra, stripped of her clothing, picked up the dual-bladed dagger, took Iphigenia's place under the cloth, and the mask covered her eyes.  Iphigenia, wearing the garb of a messenger boy, kissed her lips, lingering over them.   "Calchas is coming," she whispered. "Sweet Cassandra, I will seek your shade in Hades when my time on Earth is at an end."   Then she was gone.  Calchas entered the tent. The eyes that alit on his false princess were glittered with cold excitement.  "Take heart, princess," he said in a cruelly satisfied voice that belied the kindly words. "The ordeal ends tomorrow. Your great sacrifice will stir the winds, and the army of your father will sail forth to take Troy. You will remain forever in the memory of our people."  He drew close, his face hovering over her hidden one.  "Kiss me, and our goddess through me," he said. His hand groped between her legs.  Cassandra put her arm around his shoulder.   "Kiss me, Calchas, and your death through me."  With a mighty thrust, she yanked him down, breast to breast. Heart to heart. The dual bladed dagger sank deep into them both.  "So die two of your prophets, golden god," were her last words.

summary_P: Orpheus is signing.       He sung, his love for me. His all consuming love for Eurydice.  My sisters with shaking hands and trepidation in their eyes wove flowers in my hair. Pretending not to noticing the deadened quake in my thighs. He had saw me dance, heard me sing. And with his lyre decided we would be. He sung his songs, plucked his instrument and all who heard believed that he and me were in love. I did not know this mortal man's name, I did not love him. But the gods loved him, his honeyed voice and strings he plucked.     I could not say no....      Believe me. I tried.     Orpheus is playing      My sisters dressed me in a gown, white like our funerals.  They sang the songs they told Orpheus was love, but were the rights of our dead. Crushed lips on my berries, I can feel his rough hands on my skin. Before our marriage, pinned me down. Shoved himself between me, red is staining the white of the gown.      His white dripping down my brown thighs.      Orpheus is preparing.      My sisters take my hands, the nymph I love brushes her fingers over my lips. Orpheus is ripping up her bushes.  And the last thing I have of her is the scent of her flowers when he presents me a bouquet.      Orpheus is threatening.      My sisters walk me to a river, and we dance. Locked hands and slow for my shaking thighs and bruised insides to keep tempo. One touches my face, her hand is cold as she minds me of her own love. It is said she was turned to stone and her head removed.     Orpheus is waiting.      With closed eyes, I trust their steps and follow suit in mine.      Orpheus is watching.      I felt his eyes on me, tracing my brown skin through the white gown. The curve of my hips, the swell of my breasts, the painting of blood and himself he left in my folds. His gaze is a blight upon me.      She had never forced me into her bed.      My friend, a viper, lies in wait. And when my foot, callused and rough lands near her; she strikes.      Orpheus is wailing.      Hermes takes my hand, apologizes as he takes me from him. summary_P: He laid his body down on the soft yet somehow uncomfortable bed. Sorrow is what he felt from the moment she asked..no. told him to lay with her. He had never more so wanted to let himself unravel and climb into the lap of his wife. He had flinched when he felt an arm wrap around his. It was her he pulled away and stood up but one stern glance from her made him climb back in and accept her body leaning against his. He turned his back to her and let his body curl in on itself as he let sleep wash over him.  He thought he escaped but he only ran from her and his journey would still yet bring him to another island and another goddess but this time she didn't let him leave at least with the sorceresses..no witch he was free to leave afterwards but now he was stuck. The cold stone of the cave became comforting; it meant it was over for the meantime. When Hermes arrived he was first enthusiastic at the sight of his great grandfather and god of travel but he remembered the horrors that laid on that sea at least here he didn't have to face them sure he would deal with her but maybe it was better then what laid before him there. But he had no choice once again and left the goddess and the safety of land.  The room was still locked, the servant hanged, suitors dead, Penelope and Telemachus safe. The bed is still unmoved. He was home and now his head was on her lap as she rubbed his back while he told her of the horrors of sea and war. He paused when he got to the part about Astyanax and he refused to tell her about the Goddess and Witch. He refused to say their names. He still flinched when she tried to kiss him without warning. Sometimes he would wake up screaming, perhaps the dreams were not just because of those women but sometimes he could see the faces of those who were killed in the war or on the sea. Some were directly his fault and he knew it was.. He remembered traveling to Hades and seeing them, Ajax, Achilles, Agamemnon, and His poor mother.. gods he wished he could see her again hug her just once he missed her so so much. He also felt guilty when he would see his sister. She was often crying, Ctimene was still mourning her husband, a man who had not returned with him. Eurylochus was someone of whom Odysseus didn't get along with much but the sight of his sister crying over her late husband killed him inside perhaps he should have tried harder to stop him.  Penelope was still there, soothing him, and holding him tightly when he needed comfort or reassurance most. He hated that she saw through his facade because he loved how observant she was. She knew what people thought about him and still chose to believe in his character, despite the evidence against him. It made him love her even more. She had never once asked for anything in return from him. All those years of marriage where they could only share looks, embraces and kisses in secret and here she was offering him everything she had to give and more in return for nothing but his devotion and friendship. She deserved better so so much better.

summary_P: I don't want to say I told you so... But I told you so. I told you this would happen. But no! No one listens to me. No one listened to me and now the city walls have fallen, and the great citadel of Troy is nothing but a smoking pile of stone.  I know what you people say about me. 'Pity her, Cassandra, in her madness!' Or 'keep your eyes down, or else you'll bring the same god's wrath upon yourself!' Or if you're my mother: 'shut up Cassandra! Take her back to her room, would you?' It's not really your fault. You definitely won't believe me, but I might as well narrate my life to you- hey, you'll geta fun story out of it!  I used to be the crown jewel of the Trojan royal family, y'know? I was the beautiful and dutiful princess, devoted to her gods, to the god Apollo before all others. I was the favoured daughter, and I could have brought the family great pride by marrying a great king of a far away place, or I could have stayed home and become a favoured priestess of Apollo.  But I was too beautiful. I was too dutiful.  Men may see the attention of the gods as a good thing; see my brother Paris, favourite of Aphrodite (not that it really worked out for him), or amongst the Greeks see Odysseus and Diomedes, favoured by Athena. Men gain fame, luck, and undue honours from being a god's favourite.  Women get no such prize.  Now, I was faithful to the god Apollo before all others. I would spend hours each day in his temple, serving him, devoted above all others. And thus, he noticed me. I was in the temple one night, performing the customary daily rites to Apollo, when I started to feel tired. I thought to myself, sleeping in the temple wouldn't hurt would it? I'd done it before and nothing had happened. So I pulled out a spare straw pallet, and I fell asleep. I woke up in the middle of the night, feeling some sort of... presence watching me. So, I wake up, I blink sleep from my eyes, and I look around. There's a glowing figure at my side, and I instantly know who it is.  I've been watching you, Cassandra. He spoke. You've been so loyal, so good for me, haven't you? What if I told you I could offer you the gift of prophecy as a reward? You'd like that, wouldn't you?   And of course, I answer yes, because prophecy? Hell yeah, who'd turn that down? And in that moment, I feel his hand on my head and I see a thousand images flash before my eyes, and its beautiful.   You'd do anything for me, wouldn't you? Anything I ask of you?    And I answer yes to this as well, because when he says anything he asked of me, I assumed he'd ask for my eternal devotion to him. I assumed he'd ask for my life, and I'd willingly give it to him. I didn't assume he'd ask me for anything else, because I was twelve and devoting my doll to the temple of Artemis was just crossing the threshold of my mind.  I was twelve.  I was TWELVE!  He comes closer to me and pulls me into an embrace, and even though it's the god Apollo and he's just given me the gift of prophecy, I can't, I just can't, and I pull away from his smiling face and his face turns, and suddenly I see the displeasure in his eyes, and suddenly- A thousand of images flash before my eyes and I scream.  After that night, I was no longer the crown jewel of Troy. I was the curse upon the royal family, a blight to be locked away. I was cursed to see the future- but no one would ever believe me.  So when I saw Paris reunited with our family, I mourned for the loss of Troy over a decade before its happening. When I saw Helen enter the citadel, I screamed my lungs out and tried to tear her beautiful head from her body, hoping the gods would see it fit for her return to her lawful husband. When I saw Andromache holding little Astyanax in her arms with Hector smiling beside them, I saw her screaming out for her baby while Astyanax had his brains dashed out on the city walls. I saw Hector's dead and defiled body, feet pinned together, dragged by Achilles' chariot. I saw my mother weep for her children on the shore. I saw Polydorus' body wash up on the shore, Polyxena with her blood seeping out into the dirt, and my father dead in the same manner as his grandson.  I saw everything.  I saw my own rape at the hands of Ajax the Lesser. I can still feel his hands prying me off the statue of Athena I had clung to. I can still hear my screams as I plead to the goddess to save me, even though I knew it wouldn't change anything, because have I not always given her my dues? Have I not been pious and good? People will say that she was so moved by my pleas for mercy that grey-eyed Athena's statue turned her face away from the sight, but I call bullshit. If the so-called maiden goddess truly had pity for those of her sex, she would have saved me and every woman in Troy from those damned Greeks.  And thus now, you find me here, sitting on the shore with my family- well, the women of the family, because the men are all dead now- and the other remaining women of Troy, waiting to be picked out as war prizes for the victors.  My mother will be given to devious Odysseus, and thus will have the best fate of all of us. Poor, white-armed Andromache will be given to red-haired Neoptolemus, but will end up marrying my twin, Helenus. Polyxena is the luckiest of all, dying before she is given to someone as plunder. Helen- Helen will go back to her husband and again will become a pawn in the games of the gods.  I will be given to proud Agamemnon, and he will rape me, and I will bear him twins. He will bring me to his wife, who schemes with his cousin to kill him in revenge for the murder of her Iphigenia. She will ease him up with flattery before trapping him in a net in a bathtub, like a large mackerel caught by a fisherman, and will slay him with a sword.  She will then turn to me, bloodlust in her eyes, swinging the same sword towards me. I will sit there calmly as she kills me, because I knew this was coming, and I cannot wish for death to come soon enough.  I don't know why I'm telling you this, anyway. Not like any of you will believe me, right?

And of course, I answer yes, because prophecy? Hell yeah, who'd turn that down? And in that moment, I feel his hand on my head and I see a thousand images flash before my eyes, and its beautiful.   You'd do anything for me, wouldn't you? Anything I ask of you?    And I answer yes to this as well, because when he says anything he asked of me, I assumed he'd ask for my eternal devotion to him. I assumed he'd ask for my life, and I'd willingly give it to him. I didn't assume he'd ask me for anything else, because I was twelve and devoting my doll to the temple of Artemis was just crossing the threshold of my mind.  I was twelve.  I was TWELVE!  He comes closer to me and pulls me into an embrace, and even though it's the god Apollo and he's just given me the gift of prophecy, I can't, I just can't, and I pull away from his smiling face and his face turns, and suddenly I see the displeasure in his eyes, and suddenly- A thousand of images flash before my eyes and I scream. When I saw Helen enter the citadel, I screamed my lungs out and tried to tear her beautiful head from her body, hoping the gods would see it fit for her return to her lawful husband. I saw Hector's dead and defiled body, feet pinned together, dragged by Achilles' chariot. I saw my mother weep for her children on the shore. I saw Polydorus' body wash up on the shore, Polyxena with her blood seeping out into the dirt, and my father dead in the same manner as his grandson.  I saw everything.  I saw my own rape at the hands of Ajax the Lesser. I can still feel his hands prying me off the statue of Athena I had clung to. I can still hear my screams as I plead to the goddess to save me, even though I knew it wouldn't change anything, because have I not always given her my dues? Have I not been pious and good? People will say that she was so moved by my pleas for mercy that grey-eyed Athena's statue turned her face away from the sight, but I call bullshit. If the so-called maiden goddess truly had pity for those of her sex, she would have saved me and every woman in Troy from those damned Greeks.  And thus now, you find me here, sitting on the shore with my family- well, the women of the family, because the men are all dead now- and the other remaining women of Troy, waiting to be picked out as war prizes for the victors. Helen- Helen will go back to her husband and again will become a pawn in the games of the gods.  I will be given to proud Agamemnon, and he will rape me, and I will bear him twins. He will bring me to his wife, who schemes with his cousin to kill him in revenge for the murder of her Iphigenia. She will ease him up with flattery before trapping him in a net in a bathtub, like a large mackerel caught by a fisherman, and will slay him with a sword.  She will then turn to me, bloodlust in her eyes, swinging the same sword towards me. summary_P: Twenty years, and it seems the world has fallen apart.  Oh not for other kingdoms.  Across Greece, kingdoms were beginning to pull themselves back together, to right their world and move on from the war that had seen every able-bodied man summoned to arms.  Thebes and Pylos and Corinth and even Mycenae were now stable and thriving once more, their sons returned and their thrones filled.  Even Sparta bowed happily to their rescued Queen Helen.  Treasures from the victory at Troy filled Greek coffers and palaces.  But not Ithaca.  Ithaca still languished in uncertainty, her king neither returned nor declared dead.  Odysseus was hailed across Greece for his ingenuity.  It was his brilliance, so the rumors went, that conquered Troy at last, after a decade of war.  But where then was his share of the spoils of that victory?  Where was he?  And the rest of the men he'd taken with him?  Ten years had passed since Troy burned, and the King of Ithaca had vanished, leaving a kingdom and a wife in devastating limbo.  A generation of young men had grown up in the meantime.  Grown up without fathers and older brothers, left with only the babes in arms and the elderly and the women, wailing and grieving their husbands.  And then, as the weeks bled into months bled into years, taking the reins of power - of their children and homes and cities - into their hands.  Eurynomus was one of those children.  Only twelve when the war began, told he was too young to raise a sword, he'd watched his father and elder brother leave instead with their king.  He remembered how galling it had been when word reached the island of young Prince Neoptolemus of Phthia, sailing for Troy after the death of his hero father Achilles.  Neoptolemus was younger than Eurynomus had been at the start of the war, and yet he'd been ordered to stay behind.  Stay behind and guard his family home and support his mother, but his mother refused to heed a child too young to bear arms and serve his king.  When the years continued to pass, and returning heroes trickled home everywhere except Ithaca, Eurynomus had agreed with the other young men of his generation.  No one was coming back.  King Odysseus' vaunted divine favor had deserted him, surely he must be drowned beneath the sea, along with Eurynomus' father and brother and everyone else who'd sailed so long ago.  Ithaca must accept her tragedy and move on.  And the best way to show that would be in the remarriage of Ithaca's Queen.  Eurynomus didn't really expect wise, beautiful, Penelope to choose him.  Her cousin Helen had overlooked Eurynomus' father all those decades ago.  But Antinous had encouraged him to press his suit.  The more young men courted the Queen, the more she'd have to eventually face the harsh truth of her widowhood and the desperate need of her kingdom.  The more she'd have to choose someone.  Anyone.  And tonight would be the final confrontation.  The Queen had put them off long enough.  Now they knew her pious pleading to finish the shroud of her (former) father-in-law was nothing but a delaying tactic, they would catch her in the act.  She would choose her next husband and king tonight.  *  The maid Melantho led the pack of suitors to her mistress' quarters.  Eurynomus' fingers clenched at the sword at his hip as he skulked through the palace corridors as quietly as he could.  He saw others of his fellow suitors do the same.  Melantho stealthily opened the door to the Queen's bedchamber.  And there she was, the deceitful jade.  Hunched over her loom, painstakingly undoing her stitches by torchlight.  Queen Penelope startled as Melantho, Antinous, and Eurymachus were the first to burst inside the sanctity of her woman's chamber.  Eurynomus pushed his way forward in the middle of the crowd of men.  As they tumbled into the room, he could see Penelope's white face as she leapt to her feet.  "What is the meaning of this?  How dare you violate my chamber?"  "Us, my lady?" sneered Antinous, reaching out to grab Penelope's arm, halting her flight.  "How dare you deceive us like this?  You gave us your word, and we in our mercy and our respect for you and our deceased king allowed you this grace.  And now we see you committing such treachery.  Destroying your own work, which you'd pleaded to be your final act of widowhood.  No, my lady, you will choose your next husband tonight."  Eurynomus saw Penelope's face harden.  Gone was the modest, pious Queen hosting them.  In her place stood a goddess carved from marble, tall and grave, eyes flashing in contempt that sat oddly on her lovely, feminine face.  "It took you four years to discover such 'treachery'?  And I see from my maid's presence here tonight that it still wasn't your own realization.  And you - all of you - wonder why I refuse to choose any one of you as my husband?  Odysseus is alive and will return to me, I know that the same way I know the beat of my own heart or the pulse of my own blood.  But even if he were now a shade beneath the cold ground, I would never choose any one of you."  Eurynomus stared at her, frozen in place.  He could feel the blood rush to his cheeks as he saw her scorn.  The men around him also stood rooted in place by the force of the Queen's presence.  Silence hung for a moment, and Eurynomus held his breath with it.  And then Antinous laughed, a harsh, ugly sound.  "Then you won't choose at all."    He yanked Penelope forward into his arms and clasped her tight, creasing and bunching the fragile linen of her gown.  Eurynomus heard a soft feminine gasp at the manhandling.  The small sound should have given him pause, made his heart cringe away.  But instead, something lower stirred.  His breath hitched when Antinous pulled Penelope into a rough kiss.  Penelope's lips looked so soft and red, and the sound she made was so sweet, Eurynomus suddenly wanted nothing more than to taste her.    The man beside him leaned forward, jostling Eurynomus' arm.  Around him, men jockeyed for a better view.  He could hear others' breaths coming hot and loud as they watched Antinous kiss the Queen.    Finally, Penelope pulled away.  She was no longer the unassailable goddess as she stared at the men invading her sanctuary.  Instead, she looked shaken, frightened, smaller.  And perhaps more beautiful than Eurynomus had ever seen her.  Before anyone else could move, Antinous reached out again.  Penelope's hands came up defensively, but Antinous grabbed not for her face but the neckline of her chiton.  The loud rip of fabric made Eurynomus jump.  Penelope stood before them, bared to the waist, face flushing rapidly.  Her heaving breaths matched his own in a way that captivated him.  The switch from frozen tableau to frenzied attack was sudden and brutal.  Eurymachus began it, declaring that he wanted his turn before grabbing Penelope and pulling her into a kiss of his own.  More sounds of rent fabric filled the room, along with the lustful pans of Eurynomus and his fellow suitors and the soft, unintelligible protests from the woman they all wanted.  Then everyone was moving forward in a way, Eurynomus swept along, as they pushed and then dragged Penelope deeper into the room.  Toward the storied bed she'd shared with Odysseus so many years ago.  They gathered around the bed, and Eurynomus found himself at one corner.  For a moment, the significance of his surroundings distracted him. Across Greece, kingdoms were beginning to pull themselves back together, to right their world and move on from the war that had seen every able-bodied man summoned to arms.  Thebes and Pylos and Corinth and even Mycenae were now stable and thriving once more, their sons returned and their thrones filled.  Even Sparta bowed happily to their rescued Queen Helen.  Treasures from the victory at Troy filled Greek coffers and palaces.  But not Ithaca.  Ithaca still languished in uncertainty, her king neither returned nor declared dead.  Odysseus was hailed across Greece for his ingenuity.  It was his brilliance, so the rumors went, that conquered Troy at last, after a decade of war.  But where then was his share of the spoils of that victory?  Where was he?  And the rest of the men he'd taken with him?  Ten years had passed since Troy burned, and the King of Ithaca had vanished, leaving a kingdom and a wife in devastating limbo.  A generation of young men had grown up in the meantime.  Grown up without fathers and older brothers, left with only the babes in arms and the elderly and the women, wailing and grieving their husbands.  And then, as the weeks bled into months bled into years, taking the reins of power - of their children and homes and cities - into their hands.  Eurynomus was one of those children. Stay behind and guard his family home and support his mother, but his mother refused to heed a child too young to bear arms and serve his king. summary_P: When Riliane is young, she learns stories. Myths from worlds long gone past, dug from the ruins of a museum that dug them up from ruins. Stories where the gods can be kind or cruel, stories with dashing heroes and creatures she doesn't dare imagine. Her favorite is that of the Trojan princess Cassandra. A tragedy, and yet she memories it and carves the tale into her heart.     When she is still younger, they call her intuitive. She always seems to know when trouble will happen and avoids it. They call it reflex, hypervigilance caused by near constant assassination attempts. When she tells them she dreams of them, they tell her she is plagued by nightmares, and tell her they will fade as she grows.     When she is older, and still gets visions of things yet to happen, they call her mad behind closed doors, before swearing her to secrecy about such things in public. She is taught to feel ashamed of a talent that has saved her life many a time. She is no witch, and her dreams are not purple, so of what significance are they other than a sign of her sanity escaping. She shares a dream once, of a drought, in the council room, and that is all it takes to be outcast.     The drought happens, of course, but why worry about that when the world could point and laugh at the crazy princess, who sees things in her sleep and is convinced they are real in the daytime. If she was not the heir, they would have locked her up in a tower somewhere or sent her to a convent to be forgotten, because it is much easier to discredit than to listen.    But she is the heir, so they do the next best thing: betroth her as soon as possible and make sure the ministry will always have more power than she does. Any supporter she has after that, the ones that call her a prophetess or a Saint, quickly dissappear. But now she has a word for what she sees: prophecies.     She sees her mother's death long before it happens, yet cannot bring herself to mourn the woman who sealed her fate. So she doesn't cry, not at the funeral or her initial death. And the few tears she sheds are not for the late queen, but for the loss of her future. And the loss of a brother, not allowed to come to the palace to serve the insane princess. Perhaps that is what truly seals her fate.     She sees the future in all its bloody glory, and she knows the ministry will be her end. They are foolish, quick to take insult, and quick to line their pockets. They will spark war, and people will die, and they will come for her head. They could use her foresight, but that would require hoping off their pedestals they made for themselves. And that is unthinkable to them. He knew that I was filled with wrath and rage. Would I slit his throat in his satisfied, post-coital sleep? Would I attempt to once again invoke Athena and Apollo's wrath upon him and all the Greeks? He didn't even look at me again until the next night, when I had become numb and lay still as he explored me, trying in vain to make me rise to him.     When I realized he wanted to pretend to make love to me, to hear what sounds I made in ecstasy, I allowed him to touch me. For those moments, as he drew out my climax, I could pretend that everyone I loved was still alive, my home was not a smoldering ruin, and that I was free. When he was done with me, I slept in a dreamless escape from this existence I could not call a life.     -    The ship bounced on a wave and I lost my balance, falling backward onto the deck rather than forward into the spitting sea. I clutched my side, knowing I would rise in the morning covered in bruises. I tried to stand up but was tangled in my soaked and water-heavy chiton.    "Cassandra!" Agamemnon shouted for me, running up the steps from the hold. I said nothing, and he repeated his cry, "Cassandra!" He was now by my side, brushing my arm with his fingertips, "Are you all right?" He didn't wait for an answer and picked me up as if I were a bundle of rags. I suppose he expected me to hold him around the neck as if I were drawn to him. I let my arms hang down.    He carefully carried me down the steps into the hold, nearly banging his head as he entered. We had our own small room there, where the stolen treasures of Troy surrounded a bed. I prayed he wouldn't lay me down on it and begin to undo the brooches on my dress, telling me something heart-wrenchingly silly: that I was more beautiful than Helen, that I was the greatest treasure amongst all the plunder of Troy. Because that's what I was: plunder. I was no longer a woman, I was a thing. I was relieved when he set me down and stood me on my feet.    He stood across from me but didn't look at my face. He looked below my chin, my neck, down to where the soaked white linen revealed the darknesses of my nipples beneath. I stared blankly at him; I began to shiver violently. My whole body quaked, and I wanted to shrink to the floor and be a coddled child again. I remained silent as he again ran his hands over the droplets on my arms, brushing tears of water to the wooden floor.    I remained silent as he undid the brooches of my chiton and tenderly wrapped me in a blanket and carried me to the bed. I thought of my once-great city which was now a smoking pile of ash. Mycenae would fall one day too.     I remained silent as Agamemnon removed all of his garments and unraveled the blanket to press the warmth of his skin against me. He would try once again to plant life inside me. There was no use in telling him that as soon as we saw land we would shortly all be dead. I had given up on trying to make people believe me.     What good had it done?     My father Priam was dead.    My brothers Hector, Deiphobus, Paris, Antiphus, Pammon, Hipponous, Polydorus, and Troilus are dead.    My sisters Creusa and Polyxena are dead.    My great love Coroebus is dead.    My mother Hecuba, my sister Laodice, my twin brother Helenus...all slaves now like me, headed for unknown shores. We were all once powerful in a powerful kingdom.     We were Trojan.    There is no Troy anymore. Apollo will watch me sleeping elsewhere. I will see the sun setting in fiery pinks and oranges over a different horizon.     Agamemnon moved his hands to spread my legs.     I would die, but I knew Troy would live on in the stories told by all who knew of the dream it once was. I had foreseen it.   Lift up, heave up, carry the flame!

summary_P: In between the whistle of her father's blade and her death, Iphigenia had time for a single thought: Please, no--        She awoke in darkness, with still grass at her feet and a woman beside her. Her last moments flashed through her mind, mixed in with betrayal and grief. Slowly, she crumpled to her knees. The woman waited while she sobbed.  Some hour or days hence, when she'd cried her eyes dry, she uncurled herself and peered up at the woman, still patiently waiting. Iphigenia took stock of the endless fields--the air as silent as the skies had been at Aulis--and the woman at her side. Iphigenia got the impression of a serene, regal woman, though she couldn't seem to focus on her face.  "The Fields of Asphodel," Iphigenia guessed hollowly. Her small voice dissipated in the air, and the woman nodded. "This wasn't how it was su--supposed to. . . ." She hiccupped, the tears beginning again.  The woman's lips pressed together sternly. "No, it wasn't," she said, her voice disapproving. "The Pantheon does not see eye-to-eye on most days, and the. . . disagreement over your sacrifice was especially bitter. Which is why we have come to see you."  "We?"  The woman gave an elegant wave, and threw figures appeared behind her. "I am the Queen of the Underworld, and I have summoned the Fates. Perhaps we can rewrite your tale."  The first figure stepped forward, holding a glowing spindle in her hands. "I can re-spin the circumstances of your birth," Clotho offered. "By altering your past, no longer will you be the daughter of Agamemnon, a princess of the Greeks. In your new life, you will be the daughter of a smith. You will lead a quiet, comfortable life."  As she spoke, she drew out the thread between her fingers, and the scene materialized directly in Iphigenia's mind: a roaring fire in the hearth, a crowded table, faceless figures that she knew would be her family. Though the scene was a happy one, bitterness tugged at her heart. Instead of that comfortable warmth, her own father had lodged a dagger in her throat.  "What will become of my family? My old family," she clarified. "Who would have been sacrificed?"  She knew the answer as soon as the words left her mouth. "Your sister Electra," the figure answered.  Iphigenia blanched. She immediately, forcefully shook her head. "Though your offer is a beautiful one, I cannot accept," she murmured.  Clotho nodded and melted back into the shadows, and the second figure emerged, a single shining thread pinched between her fingers. "Then I shall create for you a different present," Lachesis suggested. "I will draw out the thread of your life, extend it past its bloody end. Tomorrow, the Myrmidons will wake with no memory of today. You will be married to Achilles, best of the Greeks, as you were told. Your marriage will be the event of your generation. Your arms and hair will be adorned with gold and jewels, on your wedding day and every day after. Achilles will treat you with kindness and dignity, and you shall want for nothing."  This time, a new scene materialized in her mind's eye. A golden wedding to a golden husband, a glittering palace to call her own. . . and then, the scene shifted. A thousand ships stranded on the shores of Aulis, a miserable and disgraceful march home. Iphigenia saw her mother and siblings ripped from their rooms and tossed in the streets, and a new king sitting upon her father's throne.  When the vision was over, she touched the tear tracks on her face. "What was that?" she whispered.  There was neither sympathy nor cruelty in Lachesis's unfeeling gaze. "Without the sacrifice, your father's army can't sail for Troy," she explained. "The people have put much into the war--in footsoldiers to fill the armies, and in material provisions. The other kings are quick to blame Agamemnon, and his favor with his people is worn thin."  "And my siblings? Electra, barely learning to walk, and Orestes, still a baby in Mother's arms. . . ." Iphigenia bowed her head. She did not need to be told how a usurper king treated his predecessor's children. Electra would be made a serving girl, and later a mistress. Orestes would be ruthlessly killed, lest he one day seek revenge.  "Thank you, but I must refuse your offer," she murmured, and the Lachesis inclined her head before fading away.  The queen Persephone took her place. "Then, are you content with your life as it played out, Child?" she asked. As she spoke, she waved her arms and conjured images of the near-present and the future. Together, they watched as the ships landed upon Trojan shores. Years of war, a generation of plague, bloodshed, and death. Then, a swift return as Agamemnon and Menelaus, the triumphant brother-kings, returned to their lands and were hailed as heroes. A long, prosperous reign before Agamemnon abdicated, and Orestes ascended as the new king. In their old age, Clytemnestra forgave Agamemnon, and at long last, he died quietly in his sleep.  All this, they watched in silence, and when the last images faded away, Iphigenia stood still, trancelike, gazing at where the visions had been.  "No," she said at last.  "No?"  Iphigenia cleared her throat, tears starting again. "No," she repeated. "I want that future for my siblings. . . for my Mother. . . but I'm angry. Furious, even! I died like a--a slaughter cow upon a slab! And I'm. . . I'm not happy to serve everyone. I should be proud. . . I should be honored. . . but I'm not. Not like this." She hung her head. "I guess I'm still a child after all," she sighed.  Persephone listened to the outburst, and then she seemed to smile. She glanced to the side, and the third figure stepped forward.  Dark shadows surrounded the last, stooped figure. "I offer you revenge," Atropos said mildly, experimentally snipping with her golden shears. "I cannot cut without a thread, and I cannot spin you another life, but of those that remain. . . ." She grinned, a sly thing with too many teeth. "I can send a whisper of intent into a ready mind," she said.  Iphigenia shivered as the images snaked through her mind: Aegisthus, a willing fool, grown too ambitious, wielding an axe placed there by Clytemnestra's hand. Her father cowering in the bath.  She closed her eyes and waited, waited for the horror to arrive. But instead of pain or remorse, something else was settling deep in her chest, something warm and filling as hot stew. Satisfaction, she realized.  She stood up straight and looked Atropos in her endless, bottomless eyes. "Do it," she said.

But Demeter noticed her absence and was (rightfully) concerned for her daughter and went to the sun god Helios (the version I know, it was Helios so we're going with that for now, if you want you can say it's apollo) and Helios was like, "Oh her? Yeah, Hades kidnapped her-" (Cue distressed screaming from demeter)  Upon finding out her daughter was, you know, kidnapped she rightfully freaked out and Helios was like, "Hey, Hades isn't the worst person to be stuck with, he's actually pretty cool, blah blah blah, misogyny is cool, blah blah-" (Cue more angry Demeter noises)  (SIDE NOTE, Misogyny is most diffidently NOT COOL BROS! Ancient Greece was not very good to women, and the stories and myths of the time reflect that as a whole, I try to keep things light hearted but some myths, such as Medusa, have heavy themes of this or these themes still slip through. Ancient Greece was pretty fucked up so just know I try my best but the stories are still gonna reflect the time period in some aspects)  -Back to our scheduled programming-  Once Demeter had calmed down from her fit of rage (Justified rage to be fair), she decided her best course of action to fill the Persephone shaped hole in her heart was.....to dress up as an old lady named Doso and become a baby sitter for this kid, Demophoon (I imagine this kid has a fair helping of childhood trauma after this lol). But along with all the normally babysitter duties she also.... planned to make him immortal so she coated him in ambrosia, breathed on him and set him on her boobs and put him to bed in a fire at night to burn away his mortal spirit....(Someone's been hanging out with Hera a little to much lol). All without his parents knowing. But, one night when she put the baby to sleep in a fire (This kid and Leo Valdez can trauma bond over this lol) his mother walked in and rightfully...freaked out, interrupting the ritual and, in some versions, killing Demophoon. Though in others he survives his night in the fire, but dies later due to the weird half immortality thing he's got going on after this whole ordeal. (She also taught Demophoon's older brother to be a farmer after this and apparently my dude travels on a dragon-drawn chariot....so...)  But after the mothers freak out, Demeter gets upset and reveals herself to be a goddess and told Demophoon's parents, the only way she'd forgive them was if they built her a temple (I'd be so confused if I was the parents in this situation).  So, the parents built her a temple and Demeter chilled there instead of Olympus and became so depressed she forgot to make plants grow and caused this huge drought/famine.  And the rest of the gods started noting and where like, "So, what the fuck is up with Demeter and why are we not getting sacrifices from the mortals anymore??"  So all the gods went to Demeter's little depression nest and tried to coax her back to Olympus or at the very least, get her to stop letting all the plants die, and they all failed. So Hermes decided to go knocking on Hades door to get some answer on Persephone and hopefully convince her to return to the mortal world so Demeter would stop being an angsty little bitch and killing all the mortals.  Persephone agreed to return with Hermes but before she left she ate 6 pomegranate seeds (In some versions I think they say it was 12 but I remember it as 6), and when she returned Demeter was finally happy again and decided she wasn't going to slowly end humanity with a lack of plants. However, because she ate the pomegranate seeds she had to stay in the underworld but Demeter and Hades got into an argument which I imagine went a little something like this,  "If you eat food in the underworld you have to stay there!"  "Oh really? Then how are you here?!"  *Cue awkward pause*  "I don't count, but she ate 6 pomegranate seeds so she has to stay in the underworld with me!"  "Well, she only had 6 seeds! Not a whole pomegranate so surely she can stay with me instead!"  *Lots of godly screaming, meanwhile Persephone and Hermes are just watching*  Hermes - "So you see that race last weekended? It was pretty cool"  Persephone - "Ah, no I missed it....was sort of kidnapped by my husband remember?"  "Oh yeah, that sucks..."  "Meh, he's got a dog though, I like dogs"  But anyways, they decided to take the matter to Zeus (Why him I'm not sure, like I know he's the king of the gods and all but...I feel like it would have made more sense for Athena to handle this one but maybe that's just me) who eventually decided that because she only ate 6 seeds, she only had to spend 6 months in the underworld. But, Demeter swore that she wouldn't let plants grow without Persephone being with her.  So now, 6 months of the year Demeter gets seasonal depression and stops making plants grow while Persephone vibes with a dog, her husband and a bunch of dead dudes for 6 months.  - The End   The myth of Pandora's box  Hey there! Remember what I said in the Hades and Persephone chapter about misogyny in ancient greece? Yeah, this might have a bit of that peaking through in parts so just, fair warning folks!  So, Pandora's box can basically be summed up as a myth explaining how people happened (least, according to the ancient greeks). Also, this and Hades and Persephone where the first greek myths I ever heard so I kinda have a soft spot for them lol.  But anyways, if we wanna start with how people happened (again, according to the ancient greeks) there were many trials and errors with creating people. When the tians where around, they created people which where actually not to bad or creepy (I will touch on the whole soulmate thing briefly here but I'll probably dedicate a chapter to it too if I'm up for it). But when Zeus took over (I'll go a chapter on the titan war at some point too) I guess he destroyed those people or something cause I can't find much about what happened to them (Then again, not entirely sure what I should be looking for in that regard so take this with a grain of salt).  The titan Prometheus (Some versions say he was a god I think? Idk, were just going with titan) could see the future, so before the whole titan war he and his brother, Epimetheus (he'll be important later), went into hiding so they didn't have to deal with it all. So when Zeus took over he created his own human race, though they sort of just stayed babies for a 100 years then died. So, he started over with a different batch of human which stayed babies for a lot less time that his first versions.  But, these humans where violent towards each other so Zeus refused to give them fire. But Prometheus gave them fire anyways, until Zeus found out he chained him to a rock and had an eagle eat his liver everyday for eternity until Heracles helped him out with it. But Zeus still wanted to punish people for having fire so he had Hephaestus create a woman named Pandora to be there punishment. (Again, misogyny is not cool folks!). The gods gifted her a dress, flowers for her hair, golden jewelry etc.  And, this is the part where the myth gets kinda fuzzy, in the kids book I had Pandora was given her box and then later her daughter was the one to open it but I don't think that version is very authentic considering it was a Max and Ruby picture book for kids so while it was the version I grew up with, I don't think it's the most accurate to the original myths.  But in some versions on the myth that I've heard she was given her box (Which was actually a storage jar in the original myths, but got changed to box threw translation errors) as one of her gifts from the gods. Prometheus (Remember him? yeah, well he can still see the future) told his brother that Zeus was going to try and arrange a marriage between Epimetheus and Pandora and then Pandora was going to unleash all her plagues and bad stuff out of the jar to screw over the entirety of humanity and that he probably shouldn't do marry her. But Epimetheus married her anyways and just like Prometheus had said she opened her box/jar and released all the evil stuff into the world (Except for hope, which I'm pretty sure stayed in the jar).  In other versions, Zeus left the jar/box in the care of Epimetheus (I think anyways) and Pandora grew curious and opened the box accidently releasing all the evil shit into the world but quickly closed it upon realizing what she did, leaving hope trapped in the jar. (Funnily enough, this isn't the first time opening jars or urns have been said to releasing bad stuff in greek myth, there's also references to it in the Iliad).  So now the mortals had to deal with sickness and famines and stuff, so Zeus decided "Fuck it" and started making a flood to whip them all out (I swear, gods all throughout different mythology and religions always resort to 'when in doubt, drown humanity', like this shows up so many times through old religions and mythologies I swear. Like, who started that? Who was the first god/goddess to drown humanity??).  But anyways, Prometheus keeps providing exposition to people despite his lack of a liver, so he goes to his son Deucalion and tells him Zeus is having his "when in doubt, drown humanity" moment so he should probably act accordingly and unlike Epimetheus, Deucalion actually decided to act accordingly by shoving himself and his wife, Pyrrha into a box so they could just vibes through Zeus's rain of terror (Literal rain of terror in this case).  So after basically vibing through Zeus's apocalypse it was sort up to them to re-populate the earth but instead of doing it the natural way they took the easy and lest incent-y (Big shocker there considering it's Greek Mythology) way to do so and just tossed some rocks around which Zeus turned into people. And this was finally the human race that stuck and didn't get wiped out (I mean, if 2020 is anything to go by there's been attempts to do so but we're, somehow, still standing!).  - The End
